title: 104_hr4076
content: The "Congress 2000 Commission Act" establishes the Congress 2000 Commission to fulfill specific duties. The Congress 2000 Commission shall analyze the size of the House of Representatives, examine alternative election methods, address declining party adherence and voter participation, and consider ways to involve more citizens in the electoral process. The Congress 2000 Commission aims to involve more citizens in the electoral process by proposing changes in the size of the House of Representatives and the method of electing Representatives. They are required to submit a report and draft legislation to implement these proposals by the end of the One Hundred Fifth Congress. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, House of Representatives, and Senate. Appointees should be qualified in politics or government. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, House of Representatives, and Senate, who serve for the life of the Commission. Members are paid the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for each day of duty and receive travel expenses. Eight members constitute a quorum, the Chairman is elected by the members, and meetings are held at the call of the Chairman or majority of members. SEC. 5. STAFF. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint up to six staff members without following standard government hiring procedures. These individuals can be paid up to the maximum rate for a GS-15 employee. Additionally, the Chairman can hire temporary services at specified rates. The Commission can hire staff members at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate for a GS-15 employee. Federal agencies can also detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services. SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission will cease to exist when its report is submitted under section 3.
